title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate EarthScience’s total revenue at the allocatively efficient quantity as $700 and/or does not show the work.

Total Revenue = Price×Quantity = $25×28 = $700 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6152@

The response calculates EarthScience’s total revenue at the allocatively efficient quantity as $700 and shows the work.

Total Revenue = Price×Quantity = $25×28 = $700 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6152@

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the quantity demanded will decrease by more than 6% and/or does not explain that the demand is elastic in this price range because marginal revenue is positive.
The response states that the quantity demanded will decrease by more than 6% and explains that the demand is elastic in this price range because marginal revenue is positive.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that at a quantity of 20 units EarthScience’s marginal product is decreasing and/or does not explain that the marginal cost is rising.
The response states that at a quantity of 20 units EarthScience’s marginal product is decreasing and explains that the marginal cost is rising.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the firm’s profit-maximizing quantity as 20 units and/or does not explain that at that quantity marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.
The response identifies that the firm’s profit-maximizing quantity as 20 units and explains that at that quantity marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the firm earns zero economic profit and/or does not explain that the firm’s average total cost curve is tangent to the demand curve, or the firm charges a price equal to the average total cost, or P = ATC = $30 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@424C@ .

The response states that the firm earns zero economic profit and explains that the firm’s average total cost curve is tangent to the demand curve, or the firm charges a price equal to the average total cost, or P = ATC = $30 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@424C@ .

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that yes, EarthScience has a dominant strategy and/or does not explain that EarthScience’s payoff is always higher when it chooses to maintain the price ( $520 > $450 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4093@ and $400 > $320 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@408C@ ) regardless of whether GeoSci chooses to advertise or not; or explain that when GeoSci chooses to advertise, EarthScience’s payoff is higher when it chooses to maintain its price ( $520 > $450 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4093@ ), and when GeoSci chooses to not advertise, EarthScience’s payoff is higher when it chooses to maintain its price ( $400 > $320 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@408C@ ); therefore, EarthScience’s dominant strategy is to maintain its price.

The response states that yes, EarthScience has a dominant strategy and explains that EarthScience’s payoff is always higher when it chooses to maintain the price ( $520 > $450 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4093@ and $400 > $320 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@408C@ ) regardless of whether GeoSci chooses to advertise or not; or explain that when GeoSci chooses to advertise, EarthScience’s payoff is higher when it chooses to maintain its price ( $520 > $450 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4093@ ), and when GeoSci chooses to not advertise, EarthScience’s payoff is higher when it chooses to maintain its price ( $400 > $320 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@408C@ ); therefore, EarthScience’s dominant strategy is to maintain its price.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify Nash equilibrium as EarthScience maintains its price and GeoSci advertises with payoffs of ($520, $460) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4136@ , and/or does not explain that if EarthScience chooses to lower its price its payoff will decrease from $520 to $450 and if GeoSci chooses to not advertise its payoff will decrease from $460 to $250; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

The response identifies the Nash equilibrium Nash equilibrium as EarthScience maintains its price and GeoSci advertises with payoffs of ($520, $460) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4136@ , and explains that if EarthScience chooses to lower its price its payoff will decrease from $520 to $450 and if GeoSci chooses to not advertise its payoff will decrease from $460 to $250; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that yes, this offer will result in a Nash equilibrium with different strategies and/or does not explain that the new strategies will be for EarthScience to lower its price and GeoSci to not advertise with payoffs of ($470, $500) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4135@ because with the offer EarthScience would earn $470 ( $320 + $150 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@407B@ ) when choosing to lower the price compared to $400 (with maintaining the price) and GeoSci would earn $500 ( = $650− $150 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4180@ ) when choosing to advertise compared to $200 ( = $350− $150 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@417D@ with not advertising). Or explain that with the offer EarthScience’s dominant strategy will change to lowering the price because its payoff will always be higher ( $600 > $520 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4090@ and $470 > $400 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4092@ ), and since GeoSci has no dominant strategy, it is better off to not advertise ( $500 > $200 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@408A@ ); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

The response states that yes, this offer will result in a Nash equilibrium with different strategies and explains that the new strategies will be for EarthScience to lower its price and GeoSci to not advertise with payoffs of ($470, $500) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4135@ because with the offer EarthScience would earn $470 ( $320 + $150 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@407B@ ) when choosing to lower the price compared to $400 (with maintaining the price) and GeoSci would earn $500 ( = $650− $150 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4180@ ) when choosing to advertise compared to $200 ( = $350− $150 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@417D@ with not advertising). Or explain that with the offer EarthScience’s dominant strategy will change to lowering the price because its payoff will always be higher ( $600 > $520 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4090@ and $470 > $400 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4092@ ), and since GeoSci has no dominant strategy, it is better off to not advertise ( $500 > $200 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@408A@ ); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.
